body: zlib check was moved in ebef55a6 so the library order may be different. Try running `make VERBOSE=1` to get more info.

It's possible. Moving ZLIB detection was the reason I waited merging this. CI didn't catch anything, and my local (curl-for-win) tests cannot catch this either because of [passing](https://github.com/curl/curl-for-win/blob/7b9d0ae2bc280537d66ce6e3334e1dd59052d2bf/curl-cmake.sh#L71-L77) `-Wl,--start-group` to the linker, due to pre-existing issues of this kind. This hack is only necessary for `ld`. `lld` (and `link.exe`) are not sensitive to lib order.

Just re-tested it, and without the hack, build fails early while detecting QUIC in quictls. This quictls build doesn't use ZLIB. According to `CMakeFiles/CMakeConfigureLog.yaml` \[1\], it breaks due to missing `winsock` symbols, despite passing `-lws2_32` as a custom flag (or even from within `CMakeLists.txt`, if added around `-lbcrypt` and others) for this detection to succeed. It ends up at the "wrong" position for `ld`.

I couldn't figure how to control lib order with CMake, but it surely would be nice to fix this class of issues.

\[1\]:
```
/usr/local/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc  -m64  -fno-ident -D_UCRT  -DHAVE_OPENSSL_SRP -DUSE_TLS_SRP 
  -DHAVE_SSL_SET0_WBIO -DHAS_ALPN -DNGHTTP2_STATICLIB -DNGHTTP3_STATICLIB
  -DNGTCP2_STATICLIB -DUSE_GSASL -I.../gsasl/x64-ucrt/usr/include -DUSE_MANUAL=1 -m64  
  -specs=.../gcc-specs-ucrt -static-libgcc  -lucrt -pedantic -Wall -W -Wpointer-arith -Wwrite-strings -Wunused 
  -Wshadow -Winline -Wnested-externs -Wmissing-declarations -Wmissing-prototypes -Wfloat-equal 
  -Wsign-compare -Wundef -Wendif-labels -Wstrict-prototypes -Wdeclaration-after-statement -Wstrict-aliasing=3 
  -Wcast-align -Wtype-limits -Wold-style-declaration -Wmissing-parameter-type -Wempty-body -Wclobbered 
  -Wignored-qualifiers -Wconversion -Wvla -Wdouble-promotion -Wenum-conversion -Warith-conversion 
  -Wno-long-long -Wno-multichar -Wno-format-nonliteral -Wno-sign-conversion -Wno-system-headers 
  -Wno-pedantic-ms-format  -Wl,--nxcompat -Wl,--dynamicbase -Wl,--high-entropy-va -Wl,-Bstatic 
  -L.../libssh2/x64-ucrt/usr/lib -L.../gsasl/x64-ucrt/usr/lib  -Wl,--pic-executable,-e,mainCRTStartup  
  -lwldap32 -lbcrypt -lbcrypt -lssh2 -lws2_32 -lgsasl  
  -Wl,--whole-archive CMakeFiles/cmTC_95f72.dir/objects.a -Wl,--no-whole-archive 
  -o cmTC_95f72.exe -Wl,--out-implib,libcmTC_95f72.dll.a 
  -Wl,--major-image-version,0,--minor-image-version,0 @CMakeFiles/cmTC_95f72.dir/linkLibs.rsp
/usr/local/Cellar/mingw-w64/10.0.0_5/toolchain-x86_64/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: .../quictls/x64-ucrt/usr/lib/libcrypto.a(libcrypto-lib-bio_addr.obj):bio_addr.c:(.text+0x26d): undefined reference to `WspiapiGetNameInfo'
/usr/local/Cellar/mingw-w64/10.0.0_5/toolchain-x86_64/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: .../quictls/x64-ucrt/usr/lib/libcrypto.a(libcrypto-lib-bio_addr.obj):bio_addr.c:(.text+0x294): undefined reference to `gai_strerrorA'
/usr/local/Cellar/mingw-w64/10.0.0_5/toolchain-x86_64/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld: .../quictls/x64-ucrt/usr/lib/libcrypto.a(libcrypto-lib-bio_addr.obj):bio_addr.c:(.text+0x2ca): undefined reference to `__imp_ntohs'
[...]
```

`linkLibs.rsp`:
```
".../quictls/x64-ucrt/usr/lib/libssl.a" ".../quictls/x64-ucrt/usr/lib/libcrypto.a" 
-lkernel32 -luser32 -lgdi32 -lwinspool -lshell32 -lole32 -loleaut32 -luuid -lcomdlg32 -ladvapi32 
```

> zlib check was moved in [ebef55a](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/ebef55a61df0094b9790710a42f63c48e7de3c13) so the library order may be different. Try running `make VERBOSE=1` to get more info.

issue.title: cmake: picky-linker fixes for openssl, ZLIB, H3 and more

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- fix HTTP/3 support detection with OpenSSL/quictls built with ZLIB.
  (Requires curl be built with ZLIB option also.)

- fix HTTP/3 support detection with OpenSSL/quictls/LibreSSL and `ld`
  linker on Windows.

- fix HTTP/3 support detection with wolfSSL to automatically add
  `ws2_32` to the lib list on Windows. For all linkers.

- reposition ZLIB (and other compression) detection _after_ TLS
  detection, but before calling HTTP/3-support detection via
  `CheckQuicSupportInOpenSSL`.

  May be a regression from ebef55a61df0094b9790710a42f63c48e7de3c13
  May fix #10832 (Reported-by: Micah Snyder)

  This also seems to fix an odd case, where OpenSSL/quictls is correctly
  detected, but its header path is not set while compiling, breaking
  build at `src/curl_ntlm_core.c`. Reason for this remains undiscovered.

- satisfy "picky" linkers such as `ld` with MinGW, that are highly
  sensitive to lib order, by also adding brotli to the beginning of the
  lib list.

- satisfy "picky" linkers by adding certain Windows systems libs to
  the lib list for OpenSSL/LibreSSL. (Might need additional ones for
  other forks, such as `pthread` for BoringSSL.)

Note: It'd make sense to _always_ add `ws2_32`, `crypt32` (except
Windows App targets perhaps?), `bcrypt` (except old-mingw!) on Windows
at this point. They are almost always required, and if some aren't,
they are ignored by the linker with no effect on final binaries.

Closes #10857

---

~~With these, a CMake build with gcc/ld _almost_ works ;) Now `gsasl` lib is in the wrong position ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯.~~ → Worked around using `CMAKE_C_STANDARD_LIBRARIES` to pass it.

body:
> Does this patch fix it?: #10857

Sorry I didn't get a chance to test this on my side in time. Been a bit hectic this week for me.

issue.title: cmake: misc tidy-ups

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- replace `add_compile_options()`,  `add_definitions()` with directory
  properties. To harmonize this across all scripts. The new commands are
  verbose, but describe better how they work. The syntax is also closer
  to setting target properties, helps grepping.

- prefer `CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX` over `--prefix` (in tests, CI).

- tidy up cmake invocations.

- formatting.

---

- [x] further split to separate PRs.
